annotation.TEXT: Remember what I said about Z Man being the most annoying boss in the game? On hindsight, I think this one is worse. Don't get me wrong, though. I love the concept of this fight (especially since it uses bosses that weren't used in the actual Wily Archive from MM10), but there's so many issues with this fight that it just drags it all down.

The other problem is, of course, Mugen 1.0's awful control delays. This is especially an issue with Hornet-Len here, given the way she attacks (don't be surprised if Mega Man just outright doesn't feel like jumping to avoid those hornets, or if Spider String misses her constantly).

With all of the bosses taken care of, we now get to take on the game's main antagonist: One going by the name of "Dr. Vinegar." For the record, I have no idea why he's called that. Bizarre names aside however, he actually has a rather neat design.

Aside from the problems addressed on the previous two bosses, this one manages to be annoying for another reason. I don't know what it is, but the hit-box on this thing seems incredibly off. It doesn't help that its weakness is the Ryuei Shield (which can easily collide with said hit-box while it's invulnerable, wasting some of its needlessly limited ammo).

The final phase is basically a Wily capsule fight, and it manages to be just as annoying as almost every other one in the original games. He's weak to the Kung Fu Board, which can only be fired as high as you can jump. Couple that in with the fact that he likes to fly just out of your reach, and you have yet another irritating fight.

For starters, all the weapons are horrible. I know that should be obvious by now - but instead of using them on custom bosses, you now get to see first-hand just how downright useless they are against actual Mega Man enemies.

There's not much to the second or third phases of this fight, although the second one is easily the most involved of them. The most damaging move comes from its oil - which on its own deals little damage and just makes the floor slippery...that is, until he shoots fire out of his head.
For the record, that wasn't doctored in by me. The game actually plays out whatever K.O. animation your screenpack happens to have in Mugen.

Time for the final boss. I have to admit - Next to DWFA's final fight and Mega Man F's ill-fated final boss, Dr. Vinegar's last machine here is easily one of the more impressive looking final foes I've come across (he almost reminds me of Zeorymer a bit, although I think it's mostly due to those nodes on his hands).

Anyways, I guess it's time for the ending evaluation? To be honest, I don't know what more I can say about this game that I haven't already addressed over these two segments. The fact that this game is capable of doing all this with the Mugen engine is impressive in its own right. The sprites are extremely well done for the most part, and the music selection is nice as well (although most of it obviously comes from Rokko-Chan, and I'm also pretty sure that this ending theme is from the Japanese version of Mega Man 8).

The biggest issue however comes from Mugen 1.0's control scheme, which limits the amount of button presses you can hold at a single time. For game mechanics like those found in Mega Man, it makes everything extremely awkward to control. This is guaranteed to lead to instances where you'll try to do something - like jump over a projectile - only for Mega Man to just stand there and take it.

Despite the neat concepts and unique creativity on display however, this game falls short in a lot of other regards. The weapon set is among the worst in any fan-game. In turn, this causes most of the bosses to become more of a pain than they should be. Speaking of bosses, most of them feel extremely unbalanced in certain regards. The damage output is all over the place (especially with Z Man), and attempting to buster duel anyone other than Kung Fu Man is practically suicide.

Did Ukege actually ever manage to achieve this greatness and fix these issues, though? Actually...Yes, he did! It took a while, but he eventually made a sequel in the form of "Rockman Infinity 2," and it manages to do everything right in the areas where this first game fell short. Given this, I think you all know what's going to be next. Tune in then, and I'll show you just how awesome the second game is.

With all this in mind however, there's easily potential for greatness in this game. The presentation is solid, there's a great amount of creativity on display, and the actual mechanics are decent enough (when Mugen 1.0 doesn't screw them up). If only the previous issues were taken care of, this game would be so much better.

The next boss has the same exact problem as the last: On its own, this is a fairly standard fight. The only issue comes from its awful weakness affiliation (Kym Knuckle). The fact that you need to hit it while its mouth is open doesn't help matters either.
Just like with the Spider Man fight, don't jump into that text box that appears by its head. For reasons I can't possibly imagine, it hurts you if you touch it.
Much like the last fight, this one has three phases. The first involves taking out the arms (which can then be used as platforms), with the second phase focusing on attacking the head itself.

With the pointless boss rush out of the way, we go straight to Dr. Vinegar's machine. Despite the fact that it has 3 phases, and even though I do a particularly horrible job at this fight, this is actually the easiest of the fortress bosses.

The final nail in the coffin is that the damage output from these bosses is way too high. Granted, the first wave isn't too bad (with the exception of Hornet-Len). The second and third waves however can easily tear you apart if you make so much as one wrong move.
He also happens to own the shortest castle in Mega Man history, mostly because it's primarily composed of boss rooms: As per evidence of this map.
